content.p: This document is a draft set of requirements for the Marco project.
content.h3: 1. Must Allow Bookmarks to be Viewed Over the Web
content.p: The service must allow bookmarks to be viewed on a web page in a format that is convenient.

div.h3: 1.1 Must Display Bookmarks for an Individual User
div.p: For each user, there are a set of bookmarks. The main way to view bookmarks will be to show all the bookmarks for a particular user.

div.h3: 1.1.1 Could Allow Users to View Other User's Bookmarks
div.p: Used in combination with a "publishing" scheme - see requirement x.x below.

div.h3: 1.2 Must Display Bookmarks by Title
div.p: The natural way to represent bookmarks is using a symbolic title provided by the user.
div.h3: 1.3 Must Allow Each Bookmark to Jump to a URL
div.p: Bookmarks also consist of a URL. No two bookmarks with the same URL can exist. The URL identifies the target location of the bookmark.
div.h3: 1.4 Must Group Bookmarks Into Categories
div.p: Most web browsers which store bookmarks store them in nested categories, which makes it easier to locate bookmarks.

div.h3: 1.4.1 Must Allow View to be Restricted to a Subset of Categories
div.p: Displaying all bookmarks in all categories all the time will make it difficult to locate bookmarks, even if you have an idea which category it is in.
div.h3: 1.4.2 Should Allow Bookmarks to Appear in More Than One Category
div.p: Sometimes it is convenient to put a bookmark in two or more different categories.
div.h3: 1.4.3 Should Display Uncategorized Bookmarks
div.p: The user may choose to categorize bookmarks at a later date.

content.h3: 2. Must Allow Bookmarks to be Edited Over the Web

div.h3: 2.1 Must Provide User-Level Authentication
div.p: It's essential that the service prevents users from modifying bookmarks for which they do not have authorization.
div.h3: 2.2 Must Allow Bookmarks to be Edited
2.2.1 Must Allow A Bookmark to be Renamed
2.2.2 Must Allow the URL of A Bookmark to be Changed
2.2.3 Must Allow A Bookmark to be Re-ordered in Its Category
2.2.4 Must Allow A Bookmark to be Moved to a Different Category
2.2.5 Must Allow A Bookmark to be Deleted
2.2.6 Should Allow A Bookmark to be Uncategorized
2.3 Must Allow Categories to be Edited
2.3.1 Must Allow A Category to be Renamed
2.3.2 Must Allow A Category to be Deleted
2.3.3 Must Allow A Category to be Re-ordered in Its Parent Category
2.3.4 Should Allow A Category to be Reparented
div.p: Categories are hierarchical. It should be possible to move categories about in the hierarchy.
div.h3: 2.3.5 Could Allow Categories to be Published
div.p: Publishing a category would allow other users to see all bookmarks and published subcategories.

content.h3: 3. Must Allow User to Administer Their Account Over the Web

div.h3: 3.1 Must Allow a User to Create a New Account
div.p: Each user is identified by their account on the service. New users should be able to create an account. An account consists of an email address, name and password.
div.h3: 3.2 Must Allow a User to Change the Email Address of Their Account
3.3 Must Allow a User to Change the Password of Their Account
3.4 Must Allow a User to Change the Name of Their Account
3.5 Must Allow a User to Close Their Account
3.6 Should Allow a User to Mail a Password, Given an Email Address
div.p: This is a common way of reminding users what their password is.

content.h3: 4. Should Provide Web-Based Administrative Control Over the Service

div.h3: 4.1 Should Allow User Accounts to Be Administered
div.p: All functionality listed under requirement 3 should be available to the administrator for any account on the service.

content.h3: 5. Should Allow Bookmarks to be Retrieved in XML Format
content.p: Providing access to bookmarks in XML allows easier application interoperability. For instance, an XML bookmarks document could be transformed using XSLT into RDF, or into XUI for embedding in Mozilla.
content.h3: 6. Should Allow Bookmarks to be Queried and Modified Programatically
content.p: Again, for application interoperability, it would be nice if the bookmarks service could be controlled and queried programatically. This should be as language-neutral as possible, for instance, as a SOAP web service.
